title: Illustration of methodology and functional of vhdi
text: package vhdi aims give valid, data-driven highest density prediction interval.

title: Illustration of methodology and functional of vhdi
text: introduce three methods generate prediction intervals robust coverage rate shortest length. Let \(\mathbf{X} = (X_1,\cdots,X_n)\) ..d random sample distribution continuous cumulative distribution function \(F\). given nominal error rate \(\alpha\), \(100((1-\alpha)\%\) prediction interval independent future observation \(X_{n+1}\) distribution random interval \((L(\mathbf{X}), U(\mathbf{X}))\) \[P(L(\mathbf{X})<X_{n+1}<U(\mathbf{X}))\geq 1-\alpha\] like use different methods find \((L(\mathbf{X}), U(\mathbf{X}))\).

title: Illustration of methodology and functional of vhdi
text: Find shortest intervals \((X_{(r)}, X_{(r+k)})\) \(\frac{k}{n+1} \geq 1-\alpha\). \(X_{(r)}\) \(r\)th order statistics \(X_1, \cdots, X_n\). Formally, \[r = \arg\min_{1\leq r \leq n-k}\{X_{(r+k)} - X_{(r)}\},\] \(k = \lceil (1-\alpha)(n+1) \rceil\). method implemented function package find highest density interval. equivalently, can search \[\beta = \arg\min_{0\leq \beta\leq \alpha}\{X_{(r+k)} - X_{(r)}\},\] \(r = \lfloor (n+1)\beta\rfloor\) \(r+k = \lceil (n+1)(1-\alpha+\beta)\rceil\). \(r\)(\(\beta\)) pre-specified chosen random, prediction interval \((X_{(r)}, X_{(r+k)})\) coverage rate least \(1-\alpha\). However, searching process introduces dependence positioning data, selected shortest prediction interval suffer -coverage problem. function searching shortest interval shortest.pi, takes data vector x nominal error rate alpha input, searches along sequence \(\beta = \{k*\alpha/50\}_{k=1}^{50}\), returns shortest interval \((X_{(r)}, X_{(r+k)})\), \(r = \lfloor (n+1)\beta\rfloor\) \(r+k = \lceil (n+1)(1-\alpha+\beta)\rceil\). Function random.pi illustrate effect picking \(\beta\) value random \((0, \alpha)\), may specify beta probability left tail. random.pi may take additional parameter beta. beta unspecified, value chosen uniformly random \((0, \alpha)\); otherwise specified beta used function. may provide random beta generated another distribution Uniform. always safer specify beta know value.
code: set.seed(100723) ## simulate data from normal distribution as an example x <- rnorm(1000) alpha <- 0.05 shortest.pi(x, alpha) #> [1] -1.893637  2.092619 ## random positioning random.pi(x, alpha) #> [1] -1.939332  2.070077  ## specify equal tailed positioning random.pi(x, alpha, beta = alpha/2) #> [1] -1.939332  2.063982  ## specify any positioning random.pi(x, alpha, alpha/10) #> [1] -2.881872  1.810862

title: Illustration of methodology and functional of vhdi
text: conservative prediction interval obtained choosing shortest intervals \((X_{(r)}, X_{(n+k)})\) \(r = 1,\cdots ,n-k\), \(k = \lceil n(1-\alpha) + 1.12\sqrt{n\alpha}\rceil\). method proposed Frey 2013 paper “Data-driven nonparametric prediction intervals”. boost nominal coverage rate going offset -coverage problem. method called conservative since achieves nominal coverage rate \(1-\alpha\) worst case scenario, .e., \[\text{inf}_{F\\mathcal{F}}P(L(\mathbf{X})<X_{n+1}<U(\mathbf{X}))\geq 1-\alpha\] \(\mathcal{F}\) set distributions consideration. Oftentimes, interval obtained method wider necessary.
code: conservative.pi(x, alpha) #> [1] -2.049211  2.070077

title: Illustration of methodology and functional of vhdi
text: idea boosting nominal coverage rate Frey(2013) adopted. Instead using coverage rate \(1-\alpha +1.12\sqrt{\frac{\alpha}{n}}\), use cross validation find new coverage rate \(1-\alpha + b\), \(b\(0,\alpha)\) stands “boost”. k-fold cross-validation, original sample randomly partitioned \(k\) equal sized subsamples. \(k\) subsamples, single subsample retained validation data testing model, remaining \(k-1\) subsamples used training data. Find shortest prediction interval nominal coverage probability \(1-\alpha+b\) using training data set evaluate empirical coverage rate testing data set. chosen \(b^*\) one accurate coverage probability testing data set. Finally use data find shortest prediction interval nominal coverage rate \(1-\alpha+b^*\). function cv.pi calculated corrected shortest prediction interval based \(K\) fold cross validation. default value K 2 reduce calculation time.

title: Illustration of methodology and functional of vhdi
text: get prediction interval simulated data function get.interval let user get prediction interval based simulated data set. supports four methods get prediction intervals: shortest correction, conservative cross-validation method, well picking random \(\beta\) value. Four types distributions possible specified function: normal, uniform, exponential gamma.  quantile calculation functions upper.quantile lower.quantile gives quantiles given data vector. data vector v length \(n\), desired probability prob, upper.quantile finds \(\lceil (n+1)prob \rceil\)th order statistic v lower.quantile finds \(\lfloor (n+1)prob \rfloor\)th order statistic v. Note prob always specifies probability mass left tail. package, upper.quantile usually used find \((1-\alpha+\beta)\times 100\) percentile lower.quantile usually used find \(\beta\times 100\) percentile.
code: # more details in ?get.interval # Example: generate the samples from standard normal distribution # use cross validation method to get the prediction interval using the generated sample res = get.interval(METHOD = 3, DIST = "Normal", n = 1000)  # things needed for the plot below lower_q = res$interval[1] upper_q = res$interval[2] data = res$data # A histogram of the sample with a shaded area representing the range of the prediction interval # inputs: sample data, lower bound of the prediction interval, upper bound of the prediction interval  # output: a plot h = hist(data, breaks=50, plot=FALSE) cuts = cut(h$breaks, c(lower_q, upper_q)) plot(h$breaks, c(h$counts,0) ,type="s",col="black", lwd=2) plot(h, col="gray"[cuts], lty="blank", add=T)

title: Illustration of methodology and functional of vhdi
text: times functions conservative.pi, shortest.pi, cv.pi get.interval may throw warning message saying “finite interval given rate, returning min(x) Inf”, due sample size large enough given coverage rate. sample size \(n\) \(\{X_1, \cdots, X_n\}\), assume \(n\) points distinct, segment real line \(n+1\) parts: \((-Inf, X_{(1)}), (X_{(1)}, X_{(2)}),\cdots, (X_{(n)}, Inf)\). finite-length interval can \(\frac{n-1}{n+1}\) coverage rate. error rate used calculation less \(\frac{2}{n+1}\), impossible get finite interval. random.pi, positioning beta can impact result well. \(\beta< \frac{1}{n+1}\), finite lower bound possible; \(\beta > \alpha - \frac{1}{n+1}\), finite upper bound possible.

title: Illustration of methodology and functional of vhdi
text: conduct 100 experiments. experiment, get prediction interval using simulated data get coverage probability prediction interval test data generated distribution simulated data. boxplot 100 coverage probabilities shown.

previous_headings: Performance evaluated using simulated data > Comparison of the coverage
title: Illustration of methodology and functional of vhdi
text: Frey(2013) mentioned, uniform distribution worst case scenario method naively searching shortest prediction interval among distributions. Intuitively, since interval length totally stands probability mass contained uniform density curve, shortest interval uniform distribution equivalent least probability. conservative prediction interval proposed Frey(2013) guarantees valid coverage uniform distribution, thus distributions.
code: n <- 1000 ## training sample size n0 <- 1000 ## test sample size alpha <- 0.05 ## nominal error rate n_exp = 100 # number of experiments n_method  = 4 # number of methods cov.box = matrix(nrow = n_exp, ncol = n_method) len.box = matrix(nrow = n_exp, ncol = n_method) for(i in 1:n_exp){   beta  = runif(1, 0, alpha)   x = runif(n)   x0  = runif(n0)      res = shortest.pi(x, alpha)   shortest_lower_q = res[1]   shortest_upper_q = res[2]   coverage.x0 = mean(shortest_lower_q<= x0 & shortest_upper_q >=x0)   cov.box[i, 1] = coverage.x0   len.box[i,1] = mean(shortest_upper_q - shortest_lower_q)      res = random.pi(x, alpha, beta)   random_lower_q = res[1]   random_upper_q = res[2]   coverage.x0 = mean(random_lower_q<= x0 & random_upper_q >=x0)   cov.box[i,2] = coverage.x0   len.box[i,2] = mean(random_upper_q - random_lower_q)      res = cv.pi(x, alpha, K = 5)   cv_lower_q = res[1]   cv_upper_q = res[2]   coverage.x0 = mean(cv_lower_q<= x0 & cv_upper_q >=x0)   cov.box[i,3] = coverage.x0   len.box[i,3] = mean(cv_upper_q - cv_lower_q)      res = conservative.pi(x, alpha)   cons_lower_q = res[1]   cons_upper_q = res[2]   coverage.x0 = mean(cons_lower_q<= x0 & cons_upper_q >=x0)   cov.box[i,4] = coverage.x0   len.box[i,4] = mean(cons_upper_q - cons_lower_q) } #> Warning in random.pi(x, alpha, beta): No finite interval at coverage given rate #> and random position.  #> Warning in random.pi(x, alpha, beta): No finite interval at coverage given rate #> and random position.  #> Warning in random.pi(x, alpha, beta): No finite interval at coverage given rate #> and random position.  boxplot(cov.box, main = paste("Coverage", expression(alpha), '=', alpha, 'Uniform'), names = c("shortest", "random", "cross validation", "conservative")) abline(h = 1-alpha, col = 'red') boxplot(len.box, main = paste("Length", expression(alpha), '=', alpha, 'Uniform'), names = c("shortest", "random", "cross validation", "conservative")) #> Warning in bplt(at[i], wid = width[i], stats = z$stats[, i], out = z$out[z$group #> == : Outlier (Inf) in boxplot 2 is not drawn

previous_headings: Performance evaluated using simulated data > Comparison of the coverage
title: Illustration of methodology and functional of vhdi
text: data skewed, naive shortest prediction interval may cover; conservative method may give wide interval data uniform.
code: n <- 1000 ## training sample size n0 <- 1000 ## test sample size alpha <- 0.05 ## nominal error rate n_exp = 100 # number of experiments n_method  = 4 # number of methods cov.box = matrix(nrow = n_exp, ncol = n_method) len.box = matrix(nrow = n_exp, ncol = n_method) for(i in 1:n_exp){   beta  = runif(1, 0, alpha)   x = rnorm(n, 0, 0.01)   x0  = rnorm(n0, 0, 0.01)      res = shortest.pi(x, alpha)   shortest_lower_q = res[1]   shortest_upper_q = res[2]   coverage.x0 = mean(shortest_lower_q<= x0 & shortest_upper_q >=x0)   cov.box[i, 1] = coverage.x0   len.box[i,1] = mean(shortest_upper_q - shortest_lower_q)      res = random.pi(x, alpha, beta)   random_lower_q = res[1]   random_upper_q = res[2]   coverage.x0 = mean(random_lower_q<= x0 & random_upper_q >=x0)   cov.box[i,2] = coverage.x0   len.box[i,2] = mean(random_upper_q - random_lower_q)      res = cv.pi(x, alpha, K = 5)   cv_lower_q = res[1]   cv_upper_q = res[2]   coverage.x0 = mean(cv_lower_q<= x0 & cv_upper_q >=x0)   cov.box[i,3] = coverage.x0   len.box[i,3] = mean(cv_upper_q - cv_lower_q)      res = conservative.pi(x, alpha)   cons_lower_q = res[1]   cons_upper_q = res[2]   coverage.x0 = mean(cons_lower_q<= x0 & cons_upper_q >=x0)   cov.box[i,4] = coverage.x0   len.box[i,4] = mean(cons_upper_q - cons_lower_q) } #> Warning in random.pi(x, alpha, beta): No finite interval at coverage given rate #> and random position.  #> Warning in random.pi(x, alpha, beta): No finite interval at coverage given rate #> and random position.  #> Warning in random.pi(x, alpha, beta): No finite interval at coverage given rate #> and random position.  #> Warning in random.pi(x, alpha, beta): No finite interval at coverage given rate #> and random position.  #> Warning in random.pi(x, alpha, beta): No finite interval at coverage given rate #> and random position.  boxplot(cov.box, main = paste("Coverage", expression(alpha), '=', alpha, 'Normal'), names = c("shortest", "random", "cross validation", "conservative")) abline(h = 1-alpha, col = 'red') boxplot(len.box, main = paste("Length", expression(alpha), '=', alpha, 'Normal'), names = c("shortest", "random", "cross validation", "conservative")) #> Warning in bplt(at[i], wid = width[i], stats = z$stats[, i], out = z$out[z$group #> == : Outlier (Inf) in boxplot 2 is not drawn

title: Illustration of methodology and functional of vhdi
text: data indeed skewed, native shortest interval searching dose suffer severe -coverage problem.
code: n <- 1000 ## training sample size n0 <- 1000 ## test sample size alpha <- 0.05 ## nominal error rate n_exp = 100 # number of experiments n_method  = 4 # number of methods cov.box = matrix(nrow = n_exp, ncol = n_method) len.box = matrix(nrow = n_exp, ncol = n_method) for(i in 1:n_exp){   beta  = runif(1, 0, alpha)   x = rlnorm(n)   x0  = rlnorm(n0)      res = shortest.pi(x, alpha)   shortest_lower_q = res[1]   shortest_upper_q = res[2]   coverage.x0 = mean(shortest_lower_q<= x0 & shortest_upper_q >=x0)   cov.box[i, 1] = coverage.x0   len.box[i,1] = mean(shortest_upper_q - shortest_lower_q)      res = random.pi(x, alpha, beta)   random_lower_q = res[1]   random_upper_q = res[2]   coverage.x0 = mean(random_lower_q<= x0 & random_upper_q >=x0)   cov.box[i,2] = coverage.x0   len.box[i,2] = mean(random_upper_q - random_lower_q)      res = cv.pi(x, alpha, K = 5)   cv_lower_q = res[1]   cv_upper_q = res[2]   coverage.x0 = mean(cv_lower_q<= x0 & cv_upper_q >=x0)   cov.box[i,3] = coverage.x0   len.box[i,3] = mean(cv_upper_q - cv_lower_q)      res = conservative.pi(x, alpha)   cons_lower_q = res[1]   cons_upper_q = res[2]   coverage.x0 = mean(cons_lower_q<= x0 & cons_upper_q >=x0)   cov.box[i,4] = coverage.x0   len.box[i,4] = mean(cons_upper_q - cons_lower_q) } #> Warning in random.pi(x, alpha, beta): No finite interval at coverage given rate #> and random position.  #> Warning in random.pi(x, alpha, beta): No finite interval at coverage given rate #> and random position.  #> Warning in random.pi(x, alpha, beta): No finite interval at coverage given rate #> and random position.  boxplot(cov.box, main = paste("Coverage", expression(alpha), '=', alpha, 'Log normal'), names = c("shortest", "random", "cross validation", "conservative")) abline(h = 1-alpha, col = 'red') boxplot(len.box, main = paste("Length", expression(alpha), '=', alpha, 'Log normal'), names = c("shortest", "random", "cross validation", "conservative")) #> Warning in bplt(at[i], wid = width[i], stats = z$stats[, i], out = z$out[z$group #> == : Outlier (Inf) in boxplot 2 is not drawn

title: Illustration of methodology and functional of vhdi
text: far, solid understanding coverage problem still absent. Since choose \(\beta\) independent data (given random positioning method), prediction intervals valid coverage rate without correction nominal error rate, believe dependence positioning data cause coverage problem. natural question whether can find appropriate correction distribution. Frey(2013) give approximate correction uniform distribution, may conservative distributions. guess skewness kurtosis distribution may impact correction needed. cross validation method works fairly well different distributions, theoretical aspect method shown yet.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Yingchao Zhou. Author, maintainer. Yichuan Bai. Author. Phan. Author. Caio dos Santos. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Zhou Y, Bai Y, Phan , dos Santos C (2023). vhdi: Prediction Interval. R package version 1.0.
code: @Manual{,   title = {vhdi: Prediction Interval},   author = {Yingchao Zhou and Yichuan Bai and An Phan and Caio {dos Santos}},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 1.0}, }

title: Prediction Interval
text: package allows generation prediction intervals robust coverage shortest length. package contains several functions compute prediction intervals data set. information, please read: Frey, J. (2013). Data-driven nonparametric prediction intervals. Journal Statistical Planning Inference, 143, 1039-1048.

title: Prediction Interval
text: can use remotes library can use devtools library
code: library(remotes) remotes::install_github("xyzyc/vhdi") library(vhdi) library(devtools) devtools::install_github("xyzyc/vhdi") library(vhdi)

title: Prediction Interval
text: three main methods get prediction intervals “shortest”, “conservative” “cross validation”. function get.interval simulates data specified distribution, calculate prediction interval using specified method. detailed description methodology functionality, see browseVignettes("vhdi").
code: x <- seq(1:100, by = 0.1)  alpha <- 0.05  shortest.pi(x, alpha) # shortest  conservative.pi(x, alpha) # conservative  cv.pi(x, alpha, K = 3) # K-fold cross validation get.interval(METHOD = "conservative", DIST = "Gamma", n = 500, alpha)

title: Conservative prediction interval — conservative.pi
text: Conservative prediction interval

title: Conservative prediction interval — conservative.pi
code: conservative.pi(x, alpha)

title: Conservative prediction interval — conservative.pi
text: x data alpha nominal error rate

title: Conservative prediction interval — conservative.pi
code: if (FALSE) { example_data <- rnorm(500, 0, 5) conservative.pi(example_data, alpha = 0.01) }

what: Cross validation for the boost of shortest prediction interval — cv.pi
title: Cross validation for the boost of shortest prediction interval — cv.pi
text: Cross validation boost shortest prediction interval

title: Cross validation for the boost of shortest prediction interval — cv.pi
code: cv.pi(x, alpha, K = 2)

title: Cross validation for the boost of shortest prediction interval — cv.pi
text: x data alpha nominal error rate K fold

title: Cross validation for the boost of shortest prediction interval — cv.pi
code: if (FALSE) { example_data <- rnorm(500, 0, 5) cv.pi(example_data, 0.01) }

what: Get the prediction interval using a simulated data set — get.interval
title: Get the prediction interval using a simulated data set — get.interval
text: Get prediction interval chosen method using simulated data set. simulated data generated standard Normal distribution, standard Uniform distribution, standard Exponential distribution standard Gamma distribution unless parameters distribution specified.

title: Get the prediction interval using a simulated data set — get.interval
code: get.interval(   METHOD = "Shortest",   DIST = "Normal",   n = 100,   test_n = 100,   alpha = 0.05,   test_data = F,   K = 2,   shape = 5,   beta,   ... )

title: Get the prediction interval using a simulated data set — get.interval
text: METHOD character string number giving method used. must match one "Random Position", "Shortest", "Cross Validation" "Conservative", default "Shortest". 1, 2, 3, 4 refer  "Random Position", "Shortest", "Cross Validation" "Conservative" respectively. DIST distribution simulated data . must match one "Normal", "Uniform", "Exponential", "Gamma", default "Normal". n Number observations simulated data test_n Number observations test data alpha nominal error rate test_data whether generate test data K k-fold cross-validation. needed METHOD "Cross Validation", default 2. shape shape parameter needed standard Gamma distribution, default 5. beta random position. needed METHOD "Random Position". beta must less equal alpha. ... arguments passed distributions

title: Get the prediction interval using a simulated data set — get.interval
text: list. interval prediction interval data simulated data test_dataset test data

title: Get the prediction interval using a simulated data set — get.interval
code: if (FALSE) { # Random position method get.interval(METHOD = "Random Position")  # Shortest method get.interval(METHOD = "Shortest")  # Uniform distribution get.interval(DIST = "Uniform")  # Normal distribution get.interval(DIST = "Normal") }

text: Calculate lower quantile data

code: lower.quantile(v, prob, sorted = FALSE)

title: Calculate the lower quantile for data — lower.quantile
text: v data want find quantile prob find lower 100*prob% quantile sorted whether v sorted

title: Calculate the lower quantile for data — lower.quantile
code: if (FALSE) { example_data <- rnorm(500, 0, 5)  # Find the lower 0.975 quantile lower.quantile(x, prob = 0.975)  # Find the lower 0.025 quantile lower.quantile(x, prob = 0.975) }
